description: Dive into the carbon-based confusion that forms the basis of life.

slides.title: What is Organic Chemistry?
slides.content:
# Carbon is King üëë

The study of the structure, properties, composition, reactions, and preparation of carbon-containing compounds.

Why Carbon?
- Can form 4 stable bonds.
- Can bond to itself (catenate) to form long chains and rings.
- Basis of all life on Earth.

slides.title: Hydrocarbons
slides.content:
# Just C and H ‚õΩ

Simplest organic compounds.

1. **Alkanes**: Single bonds ($C-C$). Saturated. (Methane, Propane).
2. **Alkenes**: Double bonds ($C=C$). Unsaturated. (Ethene typical in plastics).
3. **Alkynes**: Triple bonds ($C\equiv C$). (Acetylene torches).

slides.title: Representing Molecules
slides.content:
# Art Class üé®

- **Lewis Structure**: Shows all atoms and lone pairs.
- **Condensed**: $CH_3CH_2OH$
- **Skeletal Structure**: Lines represent bonds. Corners/Ends are Carbons. Hydrogens on Carbons are implied/hidden.

Skeletal is the lazy chemist's best friend.

slides.title: Isomers
slides.content:
# Same Parts, Different Build üß©

Molecules with the same formula but different arrangement.

- **Structural Isomers**: Different connectivity (butane vs isobutane).
- **Stereoisomers**: Same connectivity, different spatial arrangement (Cis/Trans, Enantiomers).

Mirror-image isomers (Enantiomers) can act very differently in drugs!

slides.title: Hydrocarbon Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which hydrocarbon contains a triple bond?

slides.title: Functional Groups 1
slides.content:
# The Active Sites ‚ö°

Groups of atoms that give molecules their characteristic reactions.

- **Alcohols ($R-OH$)**: Ethanol.
- **Ethers ($R-O-R$)**: Anesthetics.
- **Amines ($R-NH_2$)**: Fishy smell, bases.

slides.title: Functional Groups 2
slides.content:
# Carbonyls ($C=O$) üç¨

- **Aldehydes**: Carbonyl at the end ($R-CHO$). Vanilla.
- **Ketones**: Carbonyl in the middle ($R-CO-R$). Acetone.
- **Carboxylic Acids**: Acidic group ($R-COOH$). Vinegar.
- **Esters**: Sweet smelling ($R-COOR$). Fruits.

slides.title: IUPAC Nomenclature
slides.content:
# Naming Rules üìõ

Systematic way to name anything.

1. Find longest carbon chain Parent (Meth, Eth, Prop, But, Pent...)
2. Identify functional groups (Suffix: -ane, -ol, -oic acid).
3. Number chain to give groups lowest number.
4. Add prefixes for branches (methyl, ethyl).

slides.title: Aromatic Compounds
slides.content:
# Benzene Rings üç©

**Benzene ($C_6H_6$)**: A hexagon with alternating double bonds... actually, the electrons are delocalized around the ring.

- Very stable.
- "Aromatic" because many smell strong.
- Found in DNA bases, aspirin, and vanilla.

slides.title: Nucleophiles and Electrophiles
slides.content:
# Chemical Dating ‚ù§Ô∏è

Reactions are often "Attacker" vs "Target".

- **Nucleophile (Nu)**: Nucleus lover. Electron rich ($OH^-$). Attacks positive spots.
- **Electrophile (E)**: Electron lover. Electron poor ($H^+$). Gets attacked.

Curly arrows show electron movement from Nu to E.

slides.title: Substitution Reactions
slides.content:
# Swapping Partners üîÑ

**SN1 vs SN2**
- **SN2**: Backside attack. One step. Inverts geometry (Umbrella flip).
- **SN1**: Leaving group leaves first. Two steps. Forms carbocation intermediate.

Crucial for synthesis.

slides.title: Mechanism Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: In an SN2 reaction, how many steps are there?

slides.title: Elimination Reactions
slides.content:
# Making Double Bonds üõ§Ô∏è

Removing atoms to form a pi bond (alkene).
- E1 and E2 mechanisms (parallels SN1/SN2).
- Base takes a proton, leaving group leaves, double bond forms.

slides.title: Addition Reactions
slides.content:
# Breaking Double Bonds üî®

Adding atoms across a double bond.
- **Hydrogenation**: Adding $H_2$ (Making margarine from oil).
- **Hydration**: Adding $H_2O$ (Making alcohol from alkene).

Reverse of elimination.

slides.title: Polymers
slides.content:
# Plastics üîó

Long chains of repeating units (monomers).
- **Addition Polymers**: Polyethylene, PVC.
- **Condensation Polymers**: Nylon, Polyester (releases water).

Synthetic: Plastics, Rubber.
Natural: DNA, Proteins, Cellulose.

slides.title: Carbohydrates
slides.content:
# Sugars üç¨

Bio-organic chemistry.
- **Monosaccharides**: Glucose, Fructose.$C_6H_{12}O_6$.
- **Polysaccharides**: Starch (Energy storage), Cellulose (Plant structure).
- Lots of alcohol ($OH$) groups.

slides.title: Proteins
slides.content:
# Molecular Machines ü¶æ

Polymers of **Amino Acids**.
- Linked by Peptide Bonds (Amide).
- Fold into complex 3D shapes to function.
- Enzymes are protein catalysts.

slides.title: Lipids & Nucleic Acids
slides.content:
# Fats and DNA üß¨

- **Lipids**: Fats, oils, cell membranes. Hydrophobic (hate water).
- **Nucleic Acids**: DNA/RNA. Polymers of nucleotides. Stores genetic info.

Organic chemistry explains the code of life!

slides.title: Organic Chemistry Summary
slides.content:
# Recap üìù

- **Carbon** builds complex shapes.
- **Functional Groups** dictate reactivity.
- **Drawing structures** is the language.
- **Mechanisms** explain how bonds break and form.

From medicine to plastic to your own DNA, organic chemistry is everywhere.
